questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He also complains of sweaty palms. His appearance is as shown in the picture. Which among the following will help in the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thyroid receptor antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyroid receptor antibodies (TRAb) are the most specific test for diagnosing Graves' disease.

questions.text: Among the given options, the murmur shown in the image is associated with?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mitral Regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A pansystolic murmur extending from S1 to S2 is characteristic of mitral regurgitation .
  • ➤ pansystolic murmur
  • ➤ S1 to S2
  • ➤ mitral regurgitation

questions.text: A patient with hypertension is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown in the image. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Spironolactone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spironolactone can cause hyperkalemia , leading to ECG changes like tall T waves , wide QRS complexes , and absent P waves .
  • ➤ Spironolactone
  • ➤ hyperkalemia
  • ➤ tall T waves
  • ➤ wide QRS complexes
  • ➤ absent P waves

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of staring into space with frequent visual hallucinations. Pathology reveals Lewy bodies in neurons. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parkinson’s Disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Lewy bodies and symptoms like visual hallucinations and progressive cognitive decline point to a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease .
  • ➤ Lewy bodies
  • ➤ visual hallucinations
  • ➤ progressive cognitive decline
  • ➤ Parkinson’s disease

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. She is non-compliant with medication and appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed a blood sugar value of 500 mg/dL and the presence of ketone bodies. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. long-acting insulin

options.label: B
options.text: Intravenous fluids with S.C. regular insulin

options.label: D
options.text: Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

questions.correct_answer: D. Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Intravenous fluids with I.V. regular insulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) includes IV fluids and IV regular insulin , which is the gold standard for rapidly controlling blood glucose levels and resolving ketosis.
  • ➤ diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • ➤ IV fluids
  • ➤ IV regular insulin

questions.text: A patient with retro-positive status was started on 2nd line highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Viral load

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Viral load is the best marker for monitoring the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy (HAART) in patients with HIV, aiming to reduce it to undetectable levels to prevent disease progression and transmission.
  • ➤ Viral load
  • ➤ antiretroviral therapy (HAART)

questions.text: Which of the following would most likely lead to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Squatting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Squatting increases preload and afterload, leading to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) by reducing left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.
  • ➤ Squatting
  • ➤ decrease in the intensity of the murmur
  • ➤ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. An ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) DC shock

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with hemodynamically unstable atrial fibrillation , DC cardioversion is the immediate and most appropriate treatment to restore normal rhythm and stabilize the patient.
  • ➤ hemodynamically unstable atrial fibrillation
  • ➤ DC cardioversion

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For acute migraine management , sumatriptan is the drug of choice, as it provides rapid relief of symptoms such as headache, nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound.
  • ➤ acute migraine management
  • ➤ sumatriptan

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and aortic sclerosis presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He took 3 nitroglycerin (NTG) tablets with no relief. His vitals are stable, and cardiac enzymes were normal. An ECG on admission is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Unstable Angina

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unstable angina is a type of acute coronary syndrome where chest pain occurs without elevated cardiac enzymes or ST-segment elevation on ECG. This diagnosis is made when patients present with persistent chest pain despite normal initial tests, as seen in this case.
  • ➤ Unstable angina
  • ➤ acute coronary syndrome

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents to you with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray was done, which is shown below. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intravenous nitroglycerin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intravenous nitroglycerin is the first-line treatment for acute pulmonary edema secondary to hypertensive emergency , as it helps reduce both preload and afterload, alleviating the heart’s workload and reducing pulmonary congestion.
  • ➤ Intravenous nitroglycerin
  • ➤ acute pulmonary edema
  • ➤ hypertensive emergency

questions.text: A patient collapsed and was brought to the casualty with no proper history. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Check for responsiveness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first step in managing an unresponsive patient in Basic Life Support (BLS) is to check for responsiveness . This will guide subsequent actions such as checking for breathing and pulse, initiating CPR, and using defibrillation if necessary.
  • ➤ Basic Life Support (BLS)
  • ➤ check for responsiveness

questions.text: Which of the following is the strongest predictor of cardiovascular disease incidence and subsequent mortality due to CVD?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) LDL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Elevated LDL levels are the strongest predictor of cardiovascular disease incidence and subsequent mortality due to CVD, making LDL the primary target for therapy in both primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular events.
  • ➤ Elevated LDL levels
  • ➤ cardiovascular disease incidence
  • ➤ primary
  • ➤ secondary

questions.text: A patient on antidepressants presented to you with hypotension. An ECG was done, which showed wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV NaHCO3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of tricyclic antidepressant toxicity with wide QRS complexes , intravenous sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) is the treatment of choice, as it helps reverse the sodium channel blockade and prevents further cardiac arrhythmias.
  • ➤ tricyclic antidepressant toxicity
  • ➤ wide QRS complexes
  • ➤ intravenous sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sarcoidosis is the most likely diagnosis in patients with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy , fever , night sweats , and facial nerve palsy , a pattern commonly seen in this granulomatous disease .
  • ➤ Sarcoidosis
  • ➤ bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
  • ➤ fever
  • ➤ night sweats
  • ➤ facial nerve palsy
  • ➤ granulomatous disease

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with chest pain and was noted to have 2 mm of ST-segment elevation in his inferior leads. He has a systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 84 mm Hg and a heart rate (HR) of 124 beats/min. On examination, he is disoriented, jugular venous pressure (JVP) is elevated, and his lungs are clear. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IV Normal Saline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of right ventricular infarction (RVMI) associated with hypotension and clear lungs , the best initial treatment is IV normal saline to optimize preload and improve cardiac output.
  • ➤ right ventricular infarction (RVMI)
  • ➤ hypotension
  • ➤ clear lungs
  • ➤ IV normal saline

questions.text: A 68-year-old gentleman is brought into your ER after a syncope. The monitor showed a heart rate of 190 bpm with a blood pressure of 85/50 mmHg. His SpO2 is 98% (on NRPBM). The ECG shows a regular wide complex tachycardia (WCT) with no apparent P waves. With regard to the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, which of these features would you expect to see?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cannon a waves

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ventricular tachycardia with AV dissociation , you would expect to see cannon a waves on the JVP waveform, resulting from the atria contracting against closed AV valves due to the lack of synchronization between atrial and ventricular contractions.
  • ➤ ventricular tachycardia
  • ➤ AV dissociation
  • ➤ cannon a waves

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her chances of conception. What is the appropriate drug in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bromocriptine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For women with a prolactinoma who are trying to conceive , bromocriptine is the preferred treatment due to its well-established safety and efficacy in restoring fertility.
  • ➤ prolactinoma
  • ➤ trying to conceive
  • ➤ bromocriptine

questions.text: Which among the following, according to the latest guidelines, is NOT an indication for infective endocarditis (IE) prophylaxis?

options.label: B
options.text: Mitral Valve Prolapse with severe MR

questions.correct_answer: B. Mitral Valve Prolapse with severe MR
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mitral Valve Prolapse with severe MR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to the latest guidelines, mitral valve prolapse with severe mitral regurgitation is not an indication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis, while other high-risk conditions such as prior IE, unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease, and cardiac transplant with valvulopathy are .
  • ➤ mitral valve prolapse with severe mitral regurgitation
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ are

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a past medical history of coronary artery disease develops an MI. He got treated in CCU and before he is discharged, he undergoes echocardiography, which reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% to 40%. He is asymptomatic. What is this patient’s heart failure stage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stage B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This patient, with structural heart disease but no symptoms , fits into Stage B heart failure according to the ACC/AHA heart failure stages .
  • ➤ structural heart disease
  • ➤ no symptoms
  • ➤ Stage B
  • ➤ ACC/AHA heart failure stages

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Obstructive jaundice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obstructive jaundice is characterized by elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels, while other liver enzymes (such as AST and ALT) remain normal, indicating a biliary obstruction as the likely cause.
  • ➤ Obstructive jaundice
  • ➤ bilirubin
  • ➤ alkaline phosphatase
  • ➤ biliary obstruction

questions.text: A woman presents with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue for the past six months, along with new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lupus nephritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) symptoms and renal involvement (hematuria, RBC casts, and proteinuria) makes lupus nephritis the most likely diagnosis.
  • ➤ systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) symptoms
  • ➤ renal involvement
  • ➤ lupus nephritis

questions.text: An 11-year-old child who weighs 26 kg with a history of streptococcal pharyngitis presents with fever and arthralgia. There is no past history of rheumatic heart disease, carditis, or valvular disease. How often is benzathine penicillin recommended for the prophylaxis of rheumatic heart disease?

options.label: A
options.text: 600000 IU once in 3 weeks for 5 years

options.label: B
options.text: 600000 IU once in 3 weeks for 10 years

options.label: C
options.text: 1200000 IU once in 3 weeks for 10 years

options.label: D
options.text: 1200000 IU once in 3 weeks for life

questions.correct_answer: B. 600000 IU once in 3 weeks for 10 years
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 600000 IU once in 3 weeks for 10 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a child under 27 kg with no history of carditis , 600000 IU of benzathine penicillin every 3 weeks is the recommended dose, and the duration should continue until 21 years of age or for 10 years from the time of diagnosis.
  • ➤ 27 kg
  • ➤ no history of carditis
  • ➤ 600000 IU
  • ➤ benzathine penicillin
  • ➤ 21 years of age
  • ➤ 10 years

questions.text: A man on diuretics presents with weakness. An ECG was done which showed flat T waves and prominent U waves. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of flat T waves and prominent U waves on an ECG in a patient taking diuretics strongly suggests hypokalemia .
  • ➤ flat T waves
  • ➤ prominent U waves
  • ➤ hypokalemia

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department. The arterial blood gas (ABG) report is as follows: pH = 7.2 pCO2 = 81 mm Hg HCO3- = 40 meq/L Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Acute on chronic respiratory acidosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute on chronic respiratory acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of elevated pCO2 , elevated HCO3- , and a low pH suggests acute on chronic respiratory acidosis , commonly seen in patients with chronic respiratory conditions experiencing an acute exacerbation.
  • ➤ elevated pCO2
  • ➤ elevated HCO3-
  • ➤ low pH
  • ➤ acute on chronic respiratory acidosis

questions.text: A patient present with fever, jaundice, and malaise. Based on the following serology reports, what is the most incorrect diagnosis? Anti-HBc: Positive HBsAg: Negative Anti-HBs: Negative HBeAg: Negative
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic HBV infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic HBV infection requires the persistence of HBsAg for more than 6 months. In this case, since HBsAg is negative , chronic infection is not possible , making it the most incorrect diagnosis .
  • ➤ Chronic HBV infection
  • ➤ HBsAg
  • ➤ HBsAg is negative
  • ➤ not possible
  • ➤ incorrect diagnosis

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas reveals acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Whole Bowel Irrigation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of iron intoxication , Whole Bowel Irrigation is recommended, particularly if there are visible iron pills on abdominal X-ray. Activated charcoal is ineffective for iron overdose, and other chelators like Dimercaprol or Penicillamine are not used for iron toxicity.
  • ➤ iron intoxication
  • ➤ Whole Bowel Irrigation
  • ➤ Activated charcoal
  • ➤ Dimercaprol
  • ➤ Penicillamine

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with palpitations. Physical examination showed a diastolic murmur in the left 3rd intercostal space . What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aortic regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A diastolic murmur heard at the left 3rd intercostal space strongly suggests aortic regurgitation , where the aortic valve fails to close properly, allowing blood to flow back into the left ventricle during diastole.
  • ➤ diastolic murmur
  • ➤ left 3rd intercostal space
  • ➤ aortic regurgitation

questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought by his son because he was not using his left arm for day-to-day functioning. He has an unkempt appearance on the left side of his body and has a history of bumping into door frames while walking through them. The evaluation performed is shown in the image (clock drawing). Where does a lesion in the brain cause this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Right parietal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Left-sided hemineglect results from a lesion in the right parietal lobe , particularly in the non-dominant hemisphere , which is responsible for spatial awareness and attention.
  • ➤ Left-sided hemineglect
  • ➤ right parietal lobe
  • ➤ non-dominant hemisphere

questions.text: A person with dyspnea has a slight limitation in physical activity. Doing ordinary activities causes symptoms, but he is asymptomatic at rest. Which class of the New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification does he belong to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Class II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patient who has slight limitations in physical activity but is asymptomatic at rest falls under NYHA Class II . Ordinary activities, such as walking or climbing stairs, result in symptoms.
  • ➤ slight limitations in physical activity
  • ➤ asymptomatic at rest
  • ➤ NYHA Class II

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with headache and bitemporal hemianopia. Hormonal evaluation was normal. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gonadotroph adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patient with normal hormonal evaluation , headache , and bitemporal hemianopia is most likely to have a gonadotroph adenoma , which is the most common non-functioning pituitary adenoma .
  • ➤ normal hormonal evaluation
  • ➤ headache
  • ➤ bitemporal hemianopia
  • ➤ gonadotroph adenoma
  • ➤ non-functioning pituitary adenoma

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with prolonged menstrual bleeding. Her investigations showed normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT, while bleeding time was increased. Ristocetin test was normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glanzmann thrombasthenia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with prolonged menstrual bleeding , increased bleeding time , normal platelet count, and normal Ristocetin test , the most likely diagnosis is Glanzmann thrombasthenia , a platelet aggregation disorder.
  • ➤ prolonged menstrual bleeding
  • ➤ increased bleeding time
  • ➤ normal Ristocetin test
  • ➤ Glanzmann thrombasthenia

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with chronic pain in his hands, knees, and hips, which is aggravated by activities such as climbing stairs. He reports increased hand pain when writing or typing. He also experiences morning stiffness in his joints, lasting around 30 minutes. An X-ray of his knee shows narrowed joint space with osteophytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of chronic joint pain , morning stiffness lasting less than 1 hour , and X-ray findings of narrowed joint space with osteophytes is most consistent with osteoarthritis , a common non-inflammatory degenerative joint disease.
  • ➤ chronic joint pain
  • ➤ morning stiffness lasting less than 1 hour
  • ➤ X-ray findings
  • ➤ narrowed joint space with osteophytes
  • ➤ osteoarthritis

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. A 24-hour urine volume was measured to be 7 liters, and the urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. An ADH assay was performed, with a result of 0.8 pg/ml. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with low ADH levels , polyuria , and dilute urine , the most likely diagnosis is Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI) , where there is a deficiency of ADH leading to the inability of the kidneys to concentrate urine.
  • ➤ low ADH levels
  • ➤ polyuria
  • ➤ dilute urine
  • ➤ Central Diabetes Insipidus (DI)

questions.text: Which of the following is confirmatory to ensure that a central line is in the jugular vein?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chest X-ray

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most confirmatory method to ensure that a central line is placed correctly in the jugular vein or other central venous locations is a chest X-ray , which helps visualize the position of the catheter tip and detect any complications.
  • ➤ jugular vein
  • ➤ chest X-ray

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, restlessness, and complains of sweaty palms. Which of the following will help in diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ultrasensitive thyrotropin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of thyrotoxicosis , the most appropriate first step is to measure TSH with an ultrasensitive thyrotropin test to confirm the diagnosis before moving on to other investigations.
  • ➤ thyrotoxicosis
  • ➤ TSH
  • ➤ ultrasensitive thyrotropin

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who recently received a kidney transplant 2 months ago developed a high-grade fever, dyspnea, and a hacking cough. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Urine examination shows “owl eye” appearance of cells. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cytomegalovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a post-transplant patient with systemic symptoms and the characteristic "owl eye" inclusions , Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most likely causative agent, especially in the context of immunosuppression.
  • ➤ "owl eye" inclusions
  • ➤ Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

questions.text: A 45-year-old presents with chest pain, dyspnea that worsens when lying down and is relieved when sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled and the lungs are clear. A chest X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cardiac Tamponade

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of dyspnea, chest pain relieved by sitting upright , muffled heart sounds , and X-ray findings (likely showing an enlarged heart silhouette) strongly suggests cardiac tamponade . This is a medical emergency that requires prompt diagnosis and treatment.
  • ➤ dyspnea, chest pain relieved by sitting upright
  • ➤ muffled heart sounds
  • ➤ cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension is on multiple anti-hypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Spironolactone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spironolactone can lead to hyperkalemia , which manifests on ECG with tall T waves , widened QRS complexes , and potential absent P waves . This is the most likely cause of the ECG changes in this hypertensive patient on multiple antihypertensive medications.
  • ➤ Spironolactone
  • ➤ hyperkalemia
  • ➤ tall T waves
  • ➤ widened QRS complexes
  • ➤ absent P waves

questions.text: The patient has a fever, cough, and cold. The chest x-ray is given below. What will be the examination finding in the infra-scapular region?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dull note on percussion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of pleural effusion , a dull note on percussion is the key examination finding due to the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space.
  • ➤ pleural effusion
  • ➤ dull note on percussion

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pneumomediastinum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hamman’s sign is a crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat, and it is most commonly associated with pneumomediastinum , often heard over the precordium.
  • ➤ Hamman’s sign
  • ➤ pneumomediastinum

questions.text: A female presented with loss of pain and temperature, but her touch sensation was intact. Imaging showed cavitation around the central canal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Syringomyelia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Syringomyelia causes a selective loss of pain and temperature sensation with preservation of touch and proprioception, due to damage near the central canal of the spinal cord where the spinothalamic tract fibers cross.

questions.text: A patient has muffled heart sounds with low BP and elevated JVP. What is the likely JVP finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Absent y descent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cardiac tamponade , the y descent is absent due to impaired right atrial emptying caused by the external pressure from pericardial fluid. This finding, along with muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and elevated JVP, points to the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade.
  • ➤ cardiac tamponade
  • ➤ y descent is absent

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady develops sudden onset facial deviation with slurring of speech and inability to raise right arm. The symptoms spontaneously begin to reduce and has significant improvement over the next 2 hours. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) is characterized by the sudden onset of focal neurological symptoms that resolve within 24 hours , usually within minutes to hours. It is important to recognize TIA as it is a warning sign of a potential future stroke.
  • ➤ Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
  • ➤ sudden onset of focal neurological symptoms
  • ➤ 24 hours

questions.text: A patient had a drop in Systolic Blood Pressure of 15 mm Hg during inspiration. Which of the following is NOT associated with it?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulsus paradoxus is associated with conditions that significantly increase intrathoracic pressure during inspiration, such as cardiac tamponade , status asthmaticus , and tension pneumothorax , but not hypertrophic cardiomyopathy , which is more likely to cause pulsus bisferiens .
  • ➤ Pulsus paradoxus
  • ➤ intrathoracic pressure
  • ➤ cardiac tamponade
  • ➤ status asthmaticus
  • ➤ tension pneumothorax
  • ➤ not hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • ➤ pulsus bisferiens

questions.text: An An HIV patient presents with fever and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was done and CSF examination shows lymphocytosis, reduced An HIV patient presents with fever and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was done and CSF examination shows lymphocytosis, reduced HIV patient presents with fever and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was done and CSF examination shows lymphocytosis, reduced glucose, and increased protein. What is NOT helpful in identifying the likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CSF Viral PCR Assay

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In HIV patients with meningitis-like symptoms and CSF findings of reduced glucose and increased protein , tests for Cryptococcal meningitis and tuberculous meningitis are most useful. CSF Viral PCR Assay is not typically helpful in this context; as viral meningitis does not usually cause the same CSF abnormalities.
  • ➤ reduced glucose
  • ➤ increased protein
  • ➤ Cryptococcal meningitis
  • ➤ tuberculous meningitis
  • ➤ CSF Viral PCR Assay
  • ➤ not typically helpful

questions.text: A 2-month-pregnant female presents with swelling in her legs and is diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). She requires anticoagulation. Which of the following is preferred?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pregnancy, Enoxaparin (low molecular weight heparin) is the anticoagulant of choice for treating DVT due to its safety profile and effectiveness , while Warfarin and DOACs are contraindicated or not recommended during pregnancy.
  • ➤ Enoxaparin (low molecular weight heparin)
  • ➤ safety profile
  • ➤ effectiveness
  • ➤ Warfarin
  • ➤ DOACs

questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with weight gain and hyperpigmentation. A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test was done, and ACTH remained high before and after the test. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When ACTH remains high after a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test in a patient with signs of Cushing's syndrome , the most likely diagnosis is an ectopic ACTH-producing tumor —a common source being small cell lung carcinoma in chronic smokers.
  • ➤ ACTH remains high
  • ➤ Cushing's syndrome
  • ➤ ectopic ACTH-producing tumor
  • ➤ small cell lung carcinoma

questions.text: The patient is having the following hand movements. Which of the following conditions is responsible?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A flapping tremor (asterixis) is most commonly seen in hypercarbia and hepatic encephalopathy . It indicates underlying metabolic or toxic encephalopathy, particularly in conditions of CO2 retention.
  • ➤ flapping tremor (asterixis)
  • ➤ hypercarbia
  • ➤ hepatic encephalopathy

questions.text: A woman presented with unilateral pulsatile headache, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea, which is exaggerated on skipping her meals. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Migraine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A migraine typically presents with unilateral, pulsatile headache associated with nausea , photophobia , and phonophobia , and it may be triggered by factors like skipping meals or stress.
  • ➤ migraine
  • ➤ unilateral, pulsatile headache
  • ➤ nausea
  • ➤ photophobia
  • ➤ phonophobia
  • ➤ skipping meals

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient has fever with severe shortness of breath and red currant jelly sputum. On examination, he has altered sensorium with respiratory rate of 35 breaths/min. Lab investigations show serum creatinine of 1.9 mg/dl. CXR is done and it shows multi-lobar infiltrates. What is correct regarding the management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) ICU management (IV drugs)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe pneumonia with respiratory distress , altered sensorium , and multi-lobar infiltrates requires ICU management with IV antibiotics to ensure effective and rapid treatment, especially in suspected cases of Klebsiella pneumoniae pneumonia.
  • ➤ respiratory distress
  • ➤ altered sensorium
  • ➤ multi-lobar infiltrates
  • ➤ ICU management with IV antibiotics
  • ➤ Klebsiella pneumoniae

questions.text: 60-year-old obese lady underwent cholecystectomy. After 3 days she develops respiratory distress. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-operative respiratory distress, especially in an obese patient, should raise a high suspicion for pulmonary embolism , a common complication after surgery due to immobility and increased risk of thromboembolism. Early identification and management are crucial.
  • ➤ pulmonary embolism

questions.text: Which of the following rules out Exudative pleural effusion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Low fibrin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A low fibrin level would rule out exudative pleural effusion, as exudates are typically associated with high fibrin content due to inflammation.
  • ➤ low fibrin

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. Brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lewy bodies, composed mainly of alpha-synuclein, are a hallmark of Parkinson’s disease and are typically seen on brain biopsy in patients with this neurodegenerative disorder.
  • ➤ Parkinson’s disease

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman was on Metformin but could not achieve glycemic control. She has had a previous osteoporotic fracture and has a history of pancreatitis. The patient does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Empagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a morbidly obese diabetic patient with a history of osteoporosis and pancreatitis , Empagliflozin is the best choice for glucose management as it promotes weight loss , does not increase the risk of pancreatitis, and avoids worsening osteoporosis.
  • ➤ morbidly obese
  • ➤ osteoporosis
  • ➤ pancreatitis
  • ➤ Empagliflozin
  • ➤ weight loss

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) gets pregnant. She is currently on hydroxychloroquine and sulfasalazine, but her disease is progressively worsening at 32 weeks of gestation. Which drug can she be started on?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Certolizumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For pregnant women with rheumatoid arthritis , Certolizumab is the safest TNF-alpha inhibitor that can be used throughout pregnancy, particularly in the later stages, because it does not cross the placenta.
  • ➤ rheumatoid arthritis
  • ➤ Certolizumab
  • ➤ TNF-alpha inhibitor

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is referred for evaluation due to a 5-year history of Raynaud phenomenon and thickening of the skin over her fingers. Routine laboratory tests are within normal limits. DLCO (diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide) is 44% of normal, with normal lung volumes. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Restrictive lung disease secondary to pleural disease

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulmonary hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with systemic sclerosis , pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a common complication, especially when there is a reduced DLCO with normal lung volumes , as seen in this patient.
  • ➤ systemic sclerosis
  • ➤ pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)
  • ➤ reduced DLCO
  • ➤ normal lung volumes

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient with chronic hepatitis B who is HBeAg negative is evaluated for treatment. ALT is normal and HBV DNA is 800 IU/mL. Which of the following would you recommend for treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Observation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In chronic hepatitis B patients who are HBeAg negative , with HBV DNA < 2000 IU/mL and normal ALT , the correct management is observation and periodic monitoring. No immediate antiviral treatment is needed unless there is a change in viral load or liver enzyme levels.
  • ➤ chronic hepatitis B
  • ➤ HBeAg negative
  • ➤ HBV DNA < 2000 IU/mL
  • ➤ normal ALT
  • ➤ observation

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug can cause euglycemic Ketoacidosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Empagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Empagliflozin , an SGLT2 inhibitor, can cause euglycemic ketoacidosis , where ketoacidosis occurs with normal or mildly elevated blood glucose levels. This is a key side effect to monitor in patients treated with SGLT2 inhibitors.
  • ➤ Empagliflozin
  • ➤ euglycemic ketoacidosis

questions.text: A 22-year-old man was brought to casualty with a history of GTCS, presented with 4-5 episodes of seizures and seizures are present for more than 45 minutes. The ambulance crew administered 4 mg of lorazepam already. What will be the management in the Emergency Room?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lorazepam

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In status epilepticus, lorazepam is the first-line treatment. If the initial dose does not control the seizures, a repeat dose of lorazepam can be administered before moving on to second-line agents like phenytoin or valproate.
  • ➤ lorazepam
  • ➤ a repeat dose of lorazepam

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with long-standing type 2 diabetes came to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and frequent urination. His FBS = 144 mg/dl & PPBS = 210 mg/dl. What is the target HbA1C for adequate control of diabetes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) < 7.0

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recommended target HbA1C for most patients with type 2 diabetes is < 7% , as it balances good glycemic control with minimizing the risk of hypoglycemia and long-term complications.
  • ➤ < 7%

questions.text: All are features of Conn’s syndrome except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hallmark features of Conn’s syndrome are metabolic alkalosis , hypertension , and hypokalemia , which can result in muscle cramps. Metabolic acidosis is not associated with Conn’s syndrome.
  • ➤ metabolic alkalosis
  • ➤ hypertension
  • ➤ hypokalemia
  • ➤ Metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has ptosis and limb weakness that worsens in the evening. She was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. What is the first line drug used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyridostigmine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In myasthenia gravis , the first-line treatment is pyridostigmine , a cholinesterase inhibitor that improves muscle strength by increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction. Immunosuppressive therapies like prednisolone or cyclosporine are reserved for more severe or refractory cases. Plasma exchange is used in acute exacerbations or pre-surgical management.
  • ➤ myasthenia gravis
  • ➤ pyridostigmine
  • ➤ prednisolone
  • ➤ cyclosporine
  • ➤ Plasma exchange

questions.text: Preferred sample for testing random blood sugar is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Venous

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred sample for testing random blood sugar is venous blood because it provides the most accurate and consistent results in clinical settings. Capillary blood is often used for home monitoring and quick testing, but venous samples remain the standard for laboratory diagnostics.
  • ➤ preferred sample
  • ➤ random blood sugar
  • ➤ venous blood
  • ➤ Capillary blood

questions.text: Which value is derived in ABG?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ABG analysis , the values for pH, pO2, and pCO2 are directly measured, while bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) is derived using formulas based on the measured values.
  • ➤ ABG analysis
  • ➤ pH, pO2, and pCO2
  • ➤ bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)
  • ➤ derived

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with infertility, and he has chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. What is the likely disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kartagener’s syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kartagener’s syndrome is characterized by infertility , chronic sinusitis , bronchiectasis , and situs inversus , all due to defective ciliary movement.
  • ➤ Kartagener’s syndrome
  • ➤ infertility
  • ➤ chronic sinusitis
  • ➤ bronchiectasis
  • ➤ situs inversus

questions.text: Which of the following is likely with ascitic fluid protein 1.9 g/dL and a SAAG (Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient) of 1.4?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alcoholic cirrhosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A SAAG ≥ 1.1 g/dL and ascitic fluid protein < 2.5 g/dL are most consistent with portal hypertension due to alcoholic cirrhosis .
  • ➤ SAAG ≥ 1.1 g/dL
  • ➤ ascitic fluid protein < 2.5 g/dL
  • ➤ portal hypertension
  • ➤ alcoholic cirrhosis

questions.text: A 72-year-old pilot presents to a neurologist with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual disturbances. EEG showed periodic complexes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with rapidly progressive dementia , myoclonus , ataxia , and periodic complexes on EEG, the most likely diagnosis is Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) , a rapidly fatal neurodegenerative disease caused by prions.
  • ➤ rapidly progressive dementia
  • ➤ myoclonus
  • ➤ ataxia
  • ➤ periodic complexes
  • ➤ Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a history of recurrent headaches presented for further evaluation. Laboratory tests revealed normal hemoglobin and WBC counts, with an elevated platelet count. Bone marrow evaluation showed increased megakaryocytes and a JAK2 mutation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Essential thrombocytosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of an elevated platelet count , normal hemoglobin and WBC counts , increased megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and a JAK2 mutation is most consistent with Essential Thrombocytosis (ET) , a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by excessive platelet production.
  • ➤ elevated platelet count
  • ➤ normal hemoglobin and WBC counts
  • ➤ increased megakaryocytes
  • ➤ JAK2 mutation
  • ➤ Essential Thrombocytosis (ET)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is evaluated for shortness of breath on exertion and dry cough that have worsened over the course of 6 months. He has clubbing, and his vitals are stable. Pulmonary function tests (PFT) reveal: FEV1: 65% FVC: 67% FEV1/FVC: 74% TLC: 68% DLCO: 62% Which test is most likely to determine the etiology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HRCT chest

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with progressive dyspnea , cough , and PFT findings suggestive of a restrictive lung disease , the most appropriate next step to determine the etiology is HRCT of the chest . This imaging modality is particularly useful in diagnosing interstitial lung diseases , including idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) .
  • ➤ progressive dyspnea
  • ➤ cough
  • ➤ restrictive lung disease
  • ➤ HRCT of the chest
  • ➤ interstitial lung diseases
  • ➤ idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)

questions.text: A patient with a long history of alcoholism presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leucocytes. Investigation shows normal serum uric acid levels. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute Gout

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute gout should be strongly suspected in a patient with acute pain and swelling of the great toe (podagra), even if serum uric acid levels are normal at the time of presentation. This is because serum uric acid can be normal in up to 30-40% of acute gout cases.
  • ➤ Acute gout
  • ➤ acute pain and swelling of the great toe
  • ➤ serum uric acid levels are normal
  • ➤ serum uric acid
  • ➤ 30-40% of acute gout

questions.text: A farmer tried to commit suicide by ingesting about 2 glasses of paraquat. What is the primary system affected in paraquat toxicity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pulmonary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In paraquat poisoning , the pulmonary system is the primary system affected, with acute lung injury and eventual pulmonary fibrosis being the most critical complications.
  • ➤ paraquat poisoning
  • ➤ pulmonary system
  • ➤ acute lung injury
  • ➤ pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On auscultation, a mid-diastolic murmur is heard, and on examination, a prominent 'a' wave on the JVP is noted. What is the most appropriate diagnosis among the following options?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tricuspid Stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A mid-diastolic murmur heard at the left sternal border, combined with a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP, is most consistent with tricuspid stenosis , which causes elevated right atrial pressure and a characteristic JVP waveform.
  • ➤ mid-diastolic murmur
  • ➤ prominent 'a' wave
  • ➤ tricuspid stenosis

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness that improves with exercise and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ankylosing Spondylitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankylosing Spondylitis should be strongly suspected in young patients with morning back pain , stiffness that improves with exercise , reduced chest expansion , and extra-articular manifestations like anterior uveitis .
  • ➤ Ankylosing Spondylitis
  • ➤ morning back pain
  • ➤ stiffness that improves with exercise
  • ➤ reduced chest expansion
  • ➤ extra-articular manifestations
  • ➤ anterior uveitis

questions.text: FeNO in bronchial asthma is related to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Eosinophilic inflammation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In bronchial asthma , FeNO is primarily used to assess eosinophilic inflammation , which is associated with TH2-type inflammation. Elevated FeNO levels can help in guiding the use of biologic therapies for asthma.
  • ➤ bronchial asthma
  • ➤ FeNO
  • ➤ eosinophilic inflammation
  • ➤ TH2-type
  • ➤ biologic therapies

questions.text: A patient presents with severe restlessness and tremors to the emergency department. She has a history of bronchial asthma. On examination, a swollen neck is observed, and her blood pressure and heart rate are elevated. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs can be given in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Diltiazem

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with thyrotoxicosis-induced atrial fibrillation and a history of bronchial asthma , diltiazem is the safest choice to control the heart rate without exacerbating bronchospasm.
  • ➤ thyrotoxicosis-induced atrial fibrillation
  • ➤ bronchial asthma
  • ➤ diltiazem

questions.text: A patient undergoing hemodialysis for hyperkalemia and raised urea levels develops drowsiness, has a seizure, and becomes hypotensive during the procedure. What can be given for treatment in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mannitol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome can occur during hemodialysis , especially in patients with high urea levels, causing cerebral edema . Mannitol is the treatment of choice to reduce cerebral swelling in this condition.
  • ➤ Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome
  • ➤ hemodialysis
  • ➤ cerebral edema
  • ➤ Mannitol

questions.text: In which of the following situations would Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV) be considered contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute MI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NIV is contraindicated in patients with hemodynamically unstable acute myocardial infarction (MI) because it can exacerbate cardiac dysfunction. In cases of respiratory failure associated with AECOPD, ARDS (mild/moderate), or post-extubation, NIV can be beneficial.
  • ➤ NIV is contraindicated in patients with hemodynamically unstable acute myocardial infarction (MI)

questions.text: Which of the following improves survival in ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Low tidal volume

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ARDS , low tidal volume ventilation (LTVV) is a key intervention that improves survival by reducing ventilator-induced lung injury. Prone positioning is also beneficial, particularly in severe ARDS, but LTVV is the most established intervention for improving survival.
  • ➤ ARDS
  • ➤ low tidal volume ventilation (LTVV)
  • ➤ survival
  • ➤ Prone positioning

questions.text: Indications for a chest drain in a parapneumonic effusion include all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pleural fluid LDH > 1000

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indications for chest drainage in parapneumonic effusion include loculated fluid , pleural fluid pH < 7.2 , and glucose < 60 mg/dL . Elevated LDH > 1000 alone is not a sufficient indication for drainage without additional signs of complication.
  • ➤ chest drainage
  • ➤ parapneumonic effusion
  • ➤ loculated fluid
  • ➤ pleural fluid pH < 7.2
  • ➤ glucose < 60 mg/dL
  • ➤ LDH > 1000

questions.text: A 62-year-old smoker presents with shortness of breath (SOB) on exertion. Resting SpO2 is 94%, which reduces to 85% after walking 100 meters. Examination reveals bilateral end-inspiratory crackles. The chest CT (shown) reveals honeycombing and a pattern consistent with pulmonary fibrosis. A serologic workup for autoimmune disease is unremarkable. What is the next therapeutic option?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nintedanib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) , which is characterized by progressive fibrosis of the lungs, nintedanib is an appropriate therapeutic option as it helps to slow the progression of the disease. Other options like immunosuppressants or steroids are not effective in IPF and may be harmful.
  • ➤ idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)
  • ➤ progressive fibrosis
  • ➤ nintedanib
  • ➤ immunosuppressants
  • ➤ steroids

questions.text: A soldier operating in the Siachen Glacier presents with numbness of his legs. Based on the image provided, which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Rewarming is the treatment of choice

questions.correct_answer: A. Rewarming is the treatment of choice
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rewarming is the treatment of choice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of frostbite , like that seen in the image, rewarming is the immediate treatment of choice. Pain management is important, and in severe cases, other interventions such as thrombolytics or, in extreme situations, amputation may be considered.
  • ➤ frostbite
  • ➤ rewarming

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lateral medullary syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient’s symptoms of crossed sensory loss , dysarthria , dysphagia , and Horner’s syndrome are characteristic of lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) , most often due to posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) infarction.
  • ➤ crossed sensory loss
  • ➤ dysarthria
  • ➤ dysphagia
  • ➤ Horner’s syndrome
  • ➤ lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome)
  • ➤ posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA)

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a headache, describing it as the worst headache of his life. Initial NCCT (non-contrast CT) shows subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CT Angiography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with confirmed SAH on non-contrast CT , the next step is CT Angiography (CTA) to identify the cause, typically a ruptured aneurysm , for further therapeutic intervention.
  • ➤ confirmed SAH
  • ➤ non-contrast CT
  • ➤ CT Angiography (CTA)
  • ➤ aneurysm

questions.text: An 80-year-old man is investigated for progressive cognitive impairment. Which one of the following features is most suggestive of Lewy body dementia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neuroleptic sensitivity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuroleptic sensitivity is a key feature of Lewy body dementia (LBD) . Patients with LBD are at risk of experiencing severe adverse reactions to antipsychotic medications, making this a distinguishing clinical feature of the disease.
  • ➤ Neuroleptic sensitivity
  • ➤ Lewy body dementia (LBD)

questions.text: In Wernicke's encephalopathy, the earliest clinical feature to recover is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ophthalmoparesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Wernicke's encephalopathy , ophthalmoparesis is the earliest clinical feature to recover following thiamine therapy .
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy
  • ➤ ophthalmoparesis
  • ➤ earliest clinical feature
  • ➤ thiamine therapy

questions.text: All are accepted diagnostic criteria for acute pancreatitis except:

options.label: A
options.text: Confirmatory findings of acute pancreatitis on cross-sectional imaging

options.label: C
options.text: ≥ 3x elevation in serum lipase and/or amylase

options.label: D
options.text: Typical abdominal pain in the epigastrium that may radiate to the back

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) PaO2 < 60 mm Hg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For diagnosing acute pancreatitis , the accepted criteria are abdominal pain , elevated enzymes (amylase or lipase) , and imaging findings . A PaO2 < 60 mm Hg is part of the Ranson's criteria used for prognosis , not for diagnosis.
  • ➤ acute pancreatitis
  • ➤ abdominal pain
  • ➤ elevated enzymes (amylase or lipase)
  • ➤ imaging findings
  • ➤ PaO2 < 60 mm Hg
  • ➤ Ranson's criteria
  • ➤ prognosis

questions.text: Paraneoplastic neurological syndromes (PNS) characterized by anti-Yo antibodies are associated with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cerebellar Degeneration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-Yo antibodies are most commonly associated with paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration , particularly in patients with gynecological cancers like ovarian and breast cancer . This condition is characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia and other cerebellar signs.
  • ➤ Anti-Yo antibodies
  • ➤ paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration
  • ➤ gynecological cancers
  • ➤ ovarian
  • ➤ breast cancer
  • ➤ progressive cerebellar ataxia

questions.text: You are seeing a 20-year-old man who complains of edema and frothy urine for 2 months. Labs reveal normal serum creatinine and 4+ protein in urine without blood or bacteria. He undergoes a kidney biopsy, which is normal on light microscopy. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prednisolone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a young adult presenting with nephrotic syndrome and a normal kidney biopsy on light microscopy, minimal change disease (MCD) is the most likely diagnosis. The best initial treatment is prednisolone , as most cases of MCD respond rapidly to corticosteroid therapy.
  • ➤ nephrotic syndrome
  • ➤ normal kidney biopsy
  • ➤ minimal change disease (MCD)
  • ➤ prednisolone
  • ➤ MCD

questions.text: What is the expected MCV in the CBC based on the peripheral smear (PS) image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) > 100 fL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of hypersegmented neutrophils and macrocytes on the peripheral smear suggests megaloblastic anemia , with an MCV typically > 100 fL . This condition is commonly caused by vitamin B12 or folate deficiency .
  • ➤ hypersegmented neutrophils
  • ➤ macrocytes
  • ➤ peripheral smear
  • ➤ megaloblastic anemia
  • ➤ MCV
  • ➤ > 100 fL
  • ➤ vitamin B12
  • ➤ folate deficiency

questions.text: A 59-year-old man has an MI complicated by shock. He recovers well from the MI, but several days later, his renal function deteriorates. One week after his MI, he becomes oliguric with BUN of 53 mg/dL and creatinine of 3.9 mg/dL. What is the likely value of FeNa?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) > 2%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) , which is common after prolonged ischemia or shock, the FeNa is typically greater than 2% due to the loss of the kidney’s ability to properly reabsorb sodium.
  • ➤ acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
  • ➤ FeNa
  • ➤ greater than 2%

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of gentamicin-related AKI?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute tubular necrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely mechanism of gentamicin-related acute kidney injury is acute tubular necrosis (ATN) , resulting from direct toxic damage to the proximal tubular cells of the kidney.
  • ➤ gentamicin-related acute kidney injury
  • ➤ acute tubular necrosis (ATN)
  • ➤ toxic damage to the proximal tubular cells

questions.text: All of the following would be important for the prevention of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: Administration of IV fluids at a minimum of 3000 mL/m² daily

options.label: C
options.text: Alkalinization of the urine by administration of NaHCO3

options.label: D
options.text: Frequent monitoring of serum chemistries every 4 hours

questions.correct_answer: C. Alkalinization of the urine by administration of NaHCO3
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alkalinization of the urine by administration of NaHCO3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While hydration , allopurinol , and frequent serum monitoring are critical in tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) prevention, urine alkalinization is not recommended because it increases the risk of kidney complications, such as calcium phosphate precipitation .
  • ➤ hydration
  • ➤ allopurinol
  • ➤ frequent serum monitoring
  • ➤ tumor lysis syndrome (TLS)
  • ➤ urine alkalinization
  • ➤ not recommended
  • ➤ calcium phosphate precipitation

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the ER complaining of bleeding due to Warfarin. She received IV vitamin K, 4 U PRBCs, and 4 U FFP. Eight hours later, she begins to complain of SOB. Her vitals are T - 39°C, RR 35/min, SpO2 84% on room air, and BP 100/52 mm Hg. Exam reveals bilateral crackles, and the patient was intubated for respiratory failure. A chest X-ray (CXR) is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) TRALI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TRALI presents as acute respiratory distress , hypoxemia , and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates within 6 hours of transfusion, and it is caused by an immune-mediated response to blood products like FFP or PRBCs . This is distinct from TACO , which is related to fluid overload.
  • ➤ TRALI
  • ➤ acute respiratory distress
  • ➤ hypoxemia
  • ➤ bilateral pulmonary infiltrates
  • ➤ 6 hours
  • ➤ FFP
  • ➤ PRBCs
  • ➤ TACO

questions.text: A patient with a 5-year history of ulcerative colitis (UC) presents with acute abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A plain film is shown below. What is the next management step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IV Methylprednisolone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For severe ulcerative colitis flare-ups or early toxic megacolon , IV Methylprednisolone is the initial treatment of choice. Surgical options like subtotal colectomy are considered if there is no response to medical treatment within 48 hours or if complications arise.
  • ➤ ulcerative colitis flare-ups
  • ➤ toxic megacolon
  • ➤ IV Methylprednisolone
  • ➤ subtotal colectomy

questions.text: What is the immune mechanism leading to organ damage in Goodpasture syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Complement-activating autoantibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The immune mechanism leading to organ damage in Goodpasture syndrome involves complement-activating autoantibodies against the basement membrane in the kidneys and lungs, causing glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage .
  • ➤ immune mechanism
  • ➤ Goodpasture syndrome
  • ➤ complement-activating autoantibodies
  • ➤ basement membrane
  • ➤ glomerulonephritis
  • ➤ pulmonary hemorrhage

questions.text: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are at higher risk for all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Colorectal Cancer

  • ➤ no clear evidence

questions.text: A 40-year-old alcoholic with ascites and jaundice presents with an acute upper gastrointestinal (UGI) bleed. All of the following are appropriate treatment options EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Propranolol

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For acute variceal bleeding, treatment options include endoscopic variceal ligation , octreotide , and possibly TIPS in refractory cases. Propranolol , although effective for prevention , is not appropriate for the acute management of an ongoing variceal bleed.

  • ➤ Propranolol

  • ➤ not appropriate

questions.text: A patient with a diagnosis of diffuse cutaneous scleroderma presents with malignant hypertension, oliguria, hemolysis, and renal failure. Which of the following is the recommended treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Captopril

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Captopril (an ACE inhibitor) is the first-line treatment for scleroderma renal crisis , addressing the hypertensive emergency and improving renal function by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin system . Other antihypertensives are less effective in this specific context.
  • ➤ Captopril
  • ➤ first-line treatment

  • ➤ renin-angiotensin system

questions.text: All of the following are effective in treating Psoriatic arthritis except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rituximab

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rituximab is not effective for psoriatic arthritis , as it targets B cells rather than the TNF-alpha , IL-17 , or IL-12/23 pathways that are central to the inflammation in PsA. Effective biologic therapies for PsA typically target cytokine-mediated pathways.
  • ➤ Rituximab

  • ➤ IL-17
  • ➤ IL-12/23

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect with regards to allopurinol in gout?

options.text: Allopurinol should not be used with Colchicine

options.label: B
options.text: Allopurinol dosing should be adjusted for renal function

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Allopurinol should not be used with Colchicine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Allopurinol should not be used with Colchicine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The incorrect statement is "Allopurinol should not be used with Colchicine," as Colchicine is commonly co-prescribed with Allopurinol to prevent gout flares during the initiation of treatment.
  • ➤ "Allopurinol should not be used with Colchicine,"

  • ➤ Allopurinol

questions.text: Management of Hepatorenal Syndrome includes all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hepatorenal syndrome , diuretics like furosemide and spironolactone are contraindicated as they can worsen renal hypoperfusion. The primary treatment involves volume expansion with IV albumin , vasoactive agents (e.g., midodrine and octreotide ), and consideration of liver transplantation for definitive management.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false with regards to Klinefelter’s syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Patients are at increased risk for breast tumors

options.label: D
options.text: Most cases are diagnosed after puberty

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reduced plasma estrogen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The statement "Reduced plasma estrogen" is false in Klinefelter's syndrome , as patients have increased estrogen levels due to testicular failure . Testosterone therapy is beneficial, and there is an increased risk of breast cancer in these patients. Most cases are diagnosed after puberty.
  • ➤ "Reduced plasma estrogen"
  • ➤ Klinefelter's syndrome
  • ➤ increased estrogen levels
  • ➤ testicular failure

questions.text: A patient has neurosurgery for a pituitary tumor that requires resection of the gland. Which of the following functions of the adrenal gland will be preserved postoperatively?

options.label: A
options.text: Morning peak of plasma cortisol level

options.label: B
options.text: Release of cortisol in response to stress

options.label: C
options.text: Sodium retention in response to hypovolemia

questions.correct_answer: C. Sodium retention in response to hypovolemia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sodium retention in response to hypovolemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adrenal gland’s ability to retain sodium in response to hypovolemia is preserved post-pituitary resection because it is governed by the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) , which does not depend on ACTH . However, functions dependent on ACTH , such as cortisol production and adrenal androgen synthesis , will be compromised.
  • ➤ sodium
  • ➤ hypovolemia
  • ➤ renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS)
  • ➤ ACTH
  • ➤ ACTH
  • ➤ cortisol production
  • ➤ adrenal androgen synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the management of pheochromocytoma?

options.label: B
options.text: Salt and fluid intake should be restricted

options.label: C
options.text: IV phentolamine is indicated for hypertensive crisis

questions.correct_answer: C. IV phentolamine is indicated for hypertensive crisis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IV phentolamine is indicated for hypertensive crisis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pheochromocytoma , IV phentolamine is the first-line treatment for a hypertensive crisis . While beta-blockers can be used, they should only be given after alpha-blockade to avoid unopposed alpha stimulation. Surgery is the definitive treatment , and salt and fluid restriction should be avoided to prevent postoperative hypotension.
  • ➤ pheochromocytoma
  • ➤ IV phentolamine
  • ➤ hypertensive crisis
  • ➤ after alpha-blockade
  • ➤ definitive treatment
  • ➤ salt and fluid restriction

questions.text: A 27-year-old female develops eye pain and reduced visual acuity following the initiation of treatment for her recently diagnosed Graves' disease. Which one of the following treatments is likely to have been started?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Radioactive Iodine Ablation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radioactive iodine ablation is associated with an increased risk of worsening Graves' orbitopathy , especially in patients with existing eye symptoms. It is important to consider the risks of exacerbating eye problems when selecting treatment for patients with Graves' disease who have orbital involvement.

questions.text: Which is the characteristic pattern seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position

options.label: C
options.text: Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions

questions.correct_answer: B. Contralateral loss of pain sensation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Contralateral loss of pain sensation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Brown-Sequard syndrome , the classic characteristic is contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation due to damage to the spinothalamic tract and ipsilateral loss of motor function and proprioception below the level of the lesion.

questions.text: A patient with thalassemia has a history of multiple blood transfusions, iron overload, and cardiac arrhythmia. She has now come for a blood transfusion and during the process, complains of backache and looks very anxious. What would you do next?

options.label: B
options.text: Continue the transfusion but do an ECG

options.label: C
options.text: Stop the transfusion and wait for the patient to become normal to start it again

options.label: D
options.text: Do a clerical check and get an ECG

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In any suspected acute transfusion reaction , such as in the case of backache and anxiety during a blood transfusion, the immediate step is to stop the transfusion to prevent further complications, followed by investigations to confirm the cause of the reaction.
  • ➤ suspected acute transfusion reaction
  • ➤ backache
  • ➤ anxiety
  • ➤ immediate step
  • ➤ stop the transfusion

questions.text: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neuromyelitis optica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) presents with recurrent bilateral optic neuritis and extensive transverse myelitis . It often requires more aggressive immunosuppressive therapy beyond steroids and is distinguished from multiple sclerosis by the pattern of spinal cord involvement and optic neuritis.

  • ➤ extensive transverse myelitis
  • ➤ multiple sclerosis

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor?

options.label: C
options.text: An HLA identical matched unrelated donor

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) His HLA identical 50-year-old brother

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The optimal donor for an allogeneic stem cell transplant is typically an HLA identical sibling , as this provides the best balance between minimizing the risk of complications (such as graft-versus-host disease) and maintaining the graft-versus-leukemia effect. An HLA identical sibling is the preferred choice over unrelated donors or umbilical cord transplants.
  • ➤ optimal donor
  • ➤ HLA identical sibling

questions.text: A young child presented with nocturnal chest pain and a history of syncope, has the ECG shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Brugada syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brugada syndrome presents with characteristic ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V3 and is associated with a risk of sudden cardiac death due to ventricular arrhythmias. It should be suspected in young individuals with syncope and nocturnal chest pain, especially if these characteristic ECG findings are present.
  • ➤ Brugada syndrome
  • ➤ ST-segment elevation in leads V1-V3

questions.text: An old man presents with dyspnea and swelling of his feet. On examination, rales are heard and he is found to have an enlarged heart on chest x-ray. Which of the following will delay the progression?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Captopril

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with heart failure, Captopril (an ACE inhibitor) delays disease progression by reducing ventricular remodeling, afterload, and the progression of heart failure. It is a key drug that improves survival, unlike diuretics or digoxin, which mainly provide symptom relief.
  • ➤ Captopril (an ACE inhibitor)

questions.text: A 60-year-old with a history of COPD is brought to the ER with worsening dyspnea. ABG was done and pH was 7.3, pCO2 was 60 mmHg with HCO3- being 28 mEq/L. Which of the following is seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, hyperventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory alkalosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

options.label: C
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

options.label: D
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, adequate metabolic compensation

questions.correct_answer: C. Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis, hypoventilation, inadequate metabolic compensation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient with COPD presents with respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation and inadequate metabolic compensation , which is expected in an acute or decompensated state. The pH of 7.3 and pCO2 of 60 mmHg confirm the diagnosis of respiratory acidosis, and the mildly elevated bicarbonate (HCO3-) suggests that compensation is incomplete.
  • ➤ respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation
  • ➤ inadequate metabolic compensation

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the ECG shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mobitz type 2 block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mobitz type 2 block is characterized by a constant PR interval with intermittent dropped QRS complexes and grouped beats. It is a more severe type of AV block compared to Wenckebach and often requires pacemaker insertion due to the risk of progressing to complete heart block.
  • ➤ Mobitz type 2 block

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the ER with menorrhagia. She mentions that her father and sister also suffer from bleeding disorders. Which of the following is likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Von Willebrand Disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Von Willebrand Disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, presenting with mucosal bleeding like menorrhagia, and it affects both males and females due to its autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nelson syndrome

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nelson syndrome is characterized by hyperpigmentation and visual disturbances following bilateral adrenalectomy due to the unregulated growth of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

  • ➤ hyperpigmentation

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients is -
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Malignancy is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients due to mechanisms like PTHrP secretion , osteolytic metastases , or increased calcitriol production .

  • ➤ osteolytic metastases
  • ➤ increased calcitriol production

questions.text: Based on the ECG given below, which of the following drugs is not used in the management of the condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenosine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenosine is not used in the management of atrial fibrillation , while beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, and amiodarone are commonly used to control the rate or rhythm in AF.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome?

questions.text: A physician reviewed a patient’s chest X-ray and diagnosed COPD. The patient’s room air SaO2 is 88% and paO2 is 54 mm Hg. Which of the following will improve survival?

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife who reports that he has difficulty expressing emotions. On examination, resting tremors and rigidity are present. Which part of the brain among the following options is primarily affected in this disease?

questions.text: A young female presented with wheezing and shortness of breath with the use of accessory muscles. She complains of similar episodes in the past in early mornings. Spirometry findings are as follows: FEV1/FVC ratio < 0.7 and FEV1 < 80% of the predicted value in a female patient.

questions.text: A patient having hypertension, is on thiazides and is complaining of fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following drug can prevent potassium loss?

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient with history of mitral valve replacement on anticoagulation with warfarin is about to undergo hernioplasty for inguinal hernia. What is the target INR prior to surgery?
